{{Infobox figure skater |name= Matt Savoie |image= Matthew Savoie 2003 NHK Trophy.jpg |caption= Savoie in 2003. |country= [[United States]] |birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1980|9|12}} |residence= [[Peoria, Illinois|Peoria]], [[Illinois]] |height= {{height|m=1.75}} |coach= Linda Branan |choreographer=[[Tom Dickson]] |skating club= Illinois Valley FSC |retired= |combined total= 206.67 |combined date= [[Figure skating at the 2006 Olympics|2006 Olympics]] |SP score= 75.64 |SP date= [[2006 Four Continents]] |FS score= 137.52 |FS date= [[Figure skating at the 2006 Olympics|2006 Olympics]] |medaltemplates= <!-- see [[Template:MedalRelatedTemplates]] --> {{MedalSport | Men's [[Figure skating]]}} {{MedalCountry | [[United States]] }} {{MedalCompetition|[[Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|Four Continents Championships]]}} {{MedalBronze| [[2006 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2006 Colorado Springs]] | [[2006 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Grand Prix of Figure Skating Final|Grand Prix Final]]}} {{MedalBronze| [[2000-2001 Grand Prix of Figure Skating Final|2000–2001 Tokyo]] | [[2000-2001 Grand Prix of Figure Skating Final|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[World Junior Figure Skating Championships|World Junior Championships]]}} {{MedalBronze|[[2000 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2000 Oberstdorf]]|[[2000 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Junior Grand Prix of Figure Skating|Junior Series Final]]}} {{MedalBronze|[[1997-1998 ISU Junior Series|1997–1998 Lausanne]]|[[1997-1998 ISU Junior Grand Prix|Men's singles]]}} }}
'''Matthew Savoie''' (born September 12, 1980, in [[Peoria, Illinois]]), is an American [[Figure skating|figure skater]]. He is a three-time [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. bronze medalist]], the 2006 [[Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|Four Continents bronze medalist]] and a member of the [[United States at the 2006 Winter Olympics|2006 Olympic team]]{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}.
==Biography== Matthew Savoie first gained prominence when he won the gold medal on the junior level at the [[1997 United States Figure Skating Championships|1997 U.S. Championships]]. He went on to place in the top five at every [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. Nationals]] between 1999 and 2006, winning bronze medals in 2001, 2004, and 2006 and pewter medals (fourth place) in 1999, 2000, 2002, and 2005{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}.
He has won bronze medals at the [[ISU Junior Grand Prix Final]], the [[Grand Prix of Figure Skating Final|Grand Prix Final]], and the [[World Junior Figure Skating Championships|World Junior Championships]]. He has represented the United States three times at the [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Championships]]{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}.
Savoie was the first alternate to the [[United States at the 2002 Winter Olympics|2002 Olympic team]]. He earned a chance to compete at the [[2006 Winter Olympics]] team by finishing third at US Nationals. Savoie finished seventh overall in [[Torino]], with two solid programs{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}.
Savoie was raised in [[Peoria, Illinois]], and trained there with coach Linda Branan throughout his career. He also worked with coach Gene Hefron and choreographer [[Tom Dickson]].
He graduated [[summa cum laude]] from [[Bradley University]] in 2002, with a major in political science and a minor in biology. He went on to earn his [[master's degree]] in urban planning from the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] in 2005 and received the AICP Outstanding Graduate Student Award for 2005. He was admitted to the law school at [[Cornell University]] in 2005, but obtained a deferral for a year to focus on making the Olympic team. He joined the program in September 2006, and graduated in 2009. He is currently working as an associate in the law firm of Choate Hall & Stewart.<ref>[http://www.choate.com/people.php?PeopleID=354 Choate Hall and Stewart Biographies]</ref>
Following his competitive career, Matt completed a four-year term as the athlete representative to the Single & Pair Skating Technical Committee of the [[International Skating Union]].<ref>[http://www.usfigureskating.org/Story.asp?id=34893&type=news Welcome to U.S. Figure Skating<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
